conversation.content: Los libros no cuadran con los envíos de grano del mes pasado—nos faltan casi 140 kilos de harina según los registros del distrito. [exhales]
[measured pace] Debe ser un error de ellos, ¿no? Ya sabes cómo se pone la oficina del distrito con el papeleo, especialmente ahora que los protocolos de racionamiento cambian cada semana.
[firmly] Muéstrame los libros.
[too casual] Claro, claro, están aquí atrás en la oficina, aunque te advierto que están hechos un desastre—nunca he sido bueno para... este... para mantener las cosas organizadas, ¿sabes?
Qué raro que un hombre que no puede organizar papeles logre manejar el molino más eficiente de la provincia por 15 años seguidos.
[defensive chuckle] Moler trigo y archivar reportes son habilidades completamente distintas. Mi padre me enseñó la piedra y el grano, no la pluma y el libro mayor. [clears throat]
[quietly] La hija menor de los Brennan vino a mi oficina ayer, sana y bien alimentada, lo cual es curioso porque les revocaron las tarjetas de racionamiento hace 2 meses.
Los niños encuentran cómo comer—los vecinos comparten, las iglesias ayudan. [pause] No puedes culpar a una comunidad por evitar que sus niños se mueran de hambre, ¿verdad?
[softer] Te conozco desde que éramos niños, Tomás. Jugábamos en estos mismos campos de trigo antes de que tu padre construyera este molino, antes de la guerra, antes de todo esto.
[wavering] Y tú elegiste tu uniforme mientras yo elegí mis piedras de molino—ambos tomamos nuestras decisiones sobre lo que más importa. [heavy sigh]
[pained] No hagas esto.
¿Hacer qué, exactamente? ¿Manejar mi negocio según la ley? ¿Procesar grano según las cuotas? [bitter laugh] No he hecho nada más que seguir cada regulación que ustedes mandan.
[urgently] Mañana en la mañana mandan un equipo de inspección—inspectores de verdad, no yo, no alguien a quien le importa qué te pase a ti o al molino.
Entonces van a encontrar todo en perfecto orden, igual que tú hoy. [coughs] A menos que planees reportar algo diferente, ¿no?
[through gritted teeth] No solo estás arriesgando tu molino, estás arriesgando tu vida—ejecutan a la gente por este tipo de robo de las reservas del estado.
No es robo cuando el grano lo cultivaron campesinos que no pueden alimentar a sus propias familias por cuotas que no tienen ningún sentido. [voice rising] ¿Cómo es eso justicia?
[desperately quiet] Porque yo reporto directamente al comandante del distrito, y cuando encuentren discrepancias mañana, van a saber que te encubrí—nos van a colgar a los dos.
[stunned] ¿Ya presentaste tu reporte? [whispers] ¿Les dijiste que todo estaba bien?
Lo presenté hace una hora, dije que la harina faltante se perdió en el transporte, le eché la culpa a ataques partisanos que nunca pasaron. [hollow laugh]
[voice breaking] ¿Por qué harías—después de todo, después de elegirlos a ellos sobre nosotros, sobre lo correcto—por qué me protegerías ahora?

original_conversation.content: The ledgers don't match the grain shipments from last month—we're missing nearly three hundred pounds of flour according to the district records. [exhales]
[measured pace] Must be a clerical error on their end. You know how the district office gets with their paperwork, especially now with all the rationing protocols changing every week.
[firmly] Show me the books.
[too casual] Of course, they're right here in the back office, though I should warn you they're a mess—I've never been much good at keeping things organized, you know?
Strange how a man who can't organize paperwork manages to run the most efficient mill in the province for fifteen years straight.
[defensive chuckle] Grinding wheat and filing reports are different skills entirely. My father taught me the stone and the grain, not the pen and ledger. [clears throat]
[quietly] The Brennan family's youngest daughter came to my office yesterday, healthy and well-fed, which is curious since their ration cards were revoked two months ago.
Children find ways to eat—neighbors share, churches provide. [pause] You can't blame a community for keeping its children from starving, surely.
[softer] I've known you since we were boys, Thomas. We played in these same wheat fields before your father built this mill, before the war, before any of this.
[wavering] And you chose your uniform while I chose my millstones—we both made our decisions about what matters most. [heavy sigh]
[pained] Don't do this.
Do what, exactly? Run my business according to the law? Process grain according to the quotas? [bitter laugh] I've done nothing but follow every regulation you people send down.
[urgently] They're sending an inspection team tomorrow morning—real inspectors, not me, not someone who cares what happens to you or this mill.
Then they'll find everything in perfect order, just as you have today. [coughs] Unless you're planning to report something different?
[through gritted teeth] You're not just risking your mill, you're risking your life—they execute people for this kind of theft from the state reserves.
It's not theft when the grain was grown by farmers who can't feed their own families because of quotas that make no sense. [voice rising] How is that justice?
[desperately quiet] Because I report directly to the district commander, and when they find discrepancies tomorrow, they'll know I covered for you—we'll both hang.
[stunned] You already filed your report? [whispers] You told them everything was fine?
I filed it an hour ago, said the missing flour was lost in transport, blamed it on partisan raids that never happened. [hollow laugh]
[voice breaking] Why would you—after everything, after choosing them over us, over what's right—why would you protect me now?

scenario: During wartime rationing, a government loyalist confronts his childhood friend, the local flour miller, about discrepancies that reveal the miller has been secretly providing extra flour to blacklisted families.
